bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Tom D. Spies, November 7, 1953

div1.p: Hench informs Spies that he has heard that he, Hench, has been nominated for the decoration of Carlos Manuel de Cespedes.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Tom D. Spies, November 7, 1953
div1.opener:
November 7, 1953
Dr. Tom D. Spies
Nutrition Clinic
Hillman Hospital
Birmingham, Alabama
My dear Tom:
div1.p:
I have just heard from Lidia Cabrera, one of my yellow fever friends in
Havana that my “nomination” for the honor “Gran Oficial de laBenemerita Orden
de Carlos Manuel de Cespedes,” was published in the Havana newspapers.
She “supposed” that I might have received already the official communication
but I have heard nothing. This is all news to me and I strongly suspect
that I may never hear anything or that an official communication may find
its way to me something like that for the Finlay medal. You will remember
that thanks to you and a few others, I was supposed to have received that
honor on December 3, 1951 but never did hear from anybody and only learned
of it by accident from Mrs. Smith, I believe, when I attended your meeting.

Now, obviously, these yellow fever frields of mine, Tina Rojas and Lidia
Cabrera, have had considerable to do with this latest honor and they seem
to have hopes that it might be conferred on Finlay day but Lidia now
speaks about the possibility that I might go to Havana to help Mrs. Smith
“celebrate the Nutrition Week” and be there perhaps around January 25 to 28.

I strongly suspect from this last suggestion that you, my dear friend, have
also had a hand in all of this and have, for your own purposed, chosen not
to say anything until the matter went through. Certainly if there is any
Nutrition Week it would be nothing without you being in charge. Lidia's
letter is a most informal one and her suggestions are posed as merely pre-
liminary thinking and planning. It is all so vague and uncertain that there
is little or nothing that I can do or say, nor is it definite for me to ac-
cept anything but I just wanted you to know, first of all, that I have just
today had the first news from Havana. Secondly, I always like to visit
Havana and see my good friends there and especially if you are there to
help with the celebration. However, as I told you before, I am not a
nutritionist and am not sure whether my presence during that week would
be appropriate. Nevertheless we have some ideas regarding the use of cor-
tisone, etc., that are a distinct advance over those of two years ago and
if an invitation were forthcoming, I could doubtless work up something,
especially if publication were not required or if my hosts would be lenient
if publication were required. As a new regent of the American College
of Physicians, I have accepted the obligation to speak in Colorado Springs
January 22 and 23 but if the suggestion from Havana becomes definite, I see
no particular reason why Mary and I couldn't get to Havana by the 25th.

Now this may be all news to you as much as it is to me (though I doubt it).
If it is, please accept it as confidential information. All I can do is
to wait for some further news and instructions from my wonderful friends
in havana and in this country.
div1.closer:
Always sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
